« DR Congo records five new Ebola cases, shelves declaration of end to epidemic Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2020/04/dr-congo-records-five-new-ebola-cases-shelves-declaration-of-end-to-epidemic.html | Main Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/ | COVID-19 on Friday morning: 2,185,689 Cases, 148,634 Deaths » Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2020/04/covid-19-on-friday-morning-2185689-cases-148634-deaths.html

April 17, 2020

10 ICU beds for 1.2 million: COVID-19 catastrophe looms in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh

Via ReliefWeb, a report from Plan International: 10 ICU beds for 1.2 million: COVID-19 catastrophe looms in Cox’s Bazar - Bangladesh Link: https://reliefweb.int/report/bangladesh/10-icu-beds-12-million-covid-19-catastrophe-looms-cox-s-bazar . Excerpt:

Fear is spreading through the world’s largest refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, as a potentially devastating COVID-19 catastrophe looms. 
Director of Programmes in Cox’s Bazar for Plan International Bangladesh, Mohammed Riyas, said the medical capacity to treat COVID-19 patients in Cox’s Bazar, currently hosting close to one million Rohingya refugees, is extremely limited.  
As the township of Cox’s Bazar is now under lockdown, only essential services including provision of food, hygiene information, water and latrines and medical assistance are permitted in the Rohingya camp. Schools have closed indefinitely. Although there have been no confirmed cases within the camp so far, experts believe it is only a matter of time.  
“People in the Rohingya camps are living in fear about what they are going to do if there is a big outbreak. That fear is very real. They’ve already suffered through a war, they are not ready to face another challenge like this,” said Mr Riyas. 
Mr Riyas said there was one testing facility in Cox’s Bazar, one isolation space in the Rohingya camp and one local hospital with just 10 Intensive care beds, although the Bangladeshi Government and humanitarian agencies are working to increase this capacity. 
SOCIAL DISTANCING NOT AN OPTION IN THE CAMP 
“We are talking about one of the world’s biggest and most densely-populated refugee camps with 40,000 people per square kilometre. Social distancing is something you cannot do. Social distancing is a luxury. Here in the camp, it’s very difficult. The best chance we have is to make sure we keep the number of cases at zero.” 
Plan International is raising €100 million to protect some of the world’s most vulnerable children and their communities from the impacts of COVID-19. The organisation’s response, covering at least 50 countries including Bangladesh, is focused on assisting children - particularly girls, who are disproportionately affected by the crisis. 
The organisation’s humanitarian staff are travelling to the refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar on a daily basis to run COVID-19 information sessions, to ensure water, hygiene and sanitation facilities are operations and to continue child protection work. They wear personal protective equipment, follow strict hand-washing and social distancing protocols and undergo routine temperature checks to ensure the safety of the camp’s inhabitants. 
Mr Riyas fears a significant outbreak in the camp would see these essential services shut down altogether. 
“In the camp, if COVID-19 is widespread it’s going to be very difficult, as humanitarian operations might reduce or stop for fear of spreading the infection. This means essential services might have to cease, like provision of food and maintaining the water supply,” he said.  
“We also strongly believe that education has been severely affected by COVID-19 and we need to work with government communities to restore education and assist communities to get back to school. The online learning option is not available for these children, so we need to find other ways to ensure their education is not disrupted.” 
INFORMATION WILL SAVE LIVES 
Information sharing to counter fear and provide medical advice is a huge challenge as the camps do not have reliable or widespread internet coverage.  
Today, a coalition of 26 aid and humanitarian organisations in Bangladesh – including Plan International – have issued an open letter urging the Bangladeshi and Myanmar Governments to provide reliable internet coverage for the camp, as lack of information fuels fear and panic.

April 17, 2020 at 07:18 AM in COVID-19 Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/covid-19/ , Education and health Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/education-and-health/ , Health communication Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/health-communication/ , Healthcare systems Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/healthcare-systems/ , Refugee health Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/refugee-health/ | Permalink Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/h5n1/2020/04/10-icu-beds-for-12-million-covid-19-catastrophe-looms-in-coxs-bazar-bangladesh.html

10 ICU beds for 1.2 million: COVID-19 catastrophe looms in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh

Via ReliefWeb, a report from Plan International: 10 ICU beds for 1.2 million: COVID-19 catastrophe looms in Cox’s Bazar - Bangladesh Link: https://reliefweb.int/report/bangladesh/10-icu-beds-12-million-covid-19-catastrophe-looms-cox-s-bazar . Excerpt:

Fear is spreading through the world’s largest refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, as a potentially devastating COVID-19 catastrophe looms. 
Director of Programmes in Cox’s Bazar for Plan International Bangladesh, Mohammed Riyas, said the medical capacity to treat COVID-19 patients in Cox’s Bazar, currently hosting close to one million Rohingya refugees, is extremely limited.  
As the township of Cox’s Bazar is now under lockdown, only essential services including provision of food, hygiene information, water and latrines and medical assistance are permitted in the Rohingya camp. Schools have closed indefinitely. Although there have been no confirmed cases within the camp so far, experts believe it is only a matter of time.  
“People in the Rohingya camps are living in fear about what they are going to do if there is a big outbreak. That fear is very real. They’ve already suffered through a war, they are not ready to face another challenge like this,” said Mr Riyas. 
Mr Riyas said there was one testing facility in Cox’s Bazar, one isolation space in the Rohingya camp and one local hospital with just 10 Intensive care beds, although the Bangladeshi Government and humanitarian agencies are working to increase this capacity. 
SOCIAL DISTANCING NOT AN OPTION IN THE CAMP 
“We are talking about one of the world’s biggest and most densely-populated refugee camps with 40,000 people per square kilometre. Social distancing is something you cannot do. Social distancing is a luxury. Here in the camp, it’s very difficult. The best chance we have is to make sure we keep the number of cases at zero.” 
Plan International is raising €100 million to protect some of the world’s most vulnerable children and their communities from the impacts of COVID-19. The organisation’s response, covering at least 50 countries including Bangladesh, is focused on assisting children - particularly girls, who are disproportionately affected by the crisis. 
The organisation’s humanitarian staff are travelling to the refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar on a daily basis to run COVID-19 information sessions, to ensure water, hygiene and sanitation facilities are operations and to continue child protection work. They wear personal protective equipment, follow strict hand-washing and social distancing protocols and undergo routine temperature checks to ensure the safety of the camp’s inhabitants. 
Mr Riyas fears a significant outbreak in the camp would see these essential services shut down altogether. 
“In the camp, if COVID-19 is widespread it’s going to be very difficult, as humanitarian operations might reduce or stop for fear of spreading the infection. This means essential services might have to cease, like provision of food and maintaining the water supply,” he said.  
“We also strongly believe that education has been severely affected by COVID-19 and we need to work with government communities to restore education and assist communities to get back to school. The online learning option is not available for these children, so we need to find other ways to ensure their education is not disrupted.” 
INFORMATION WILL SAVE LIVES 
Information sharing to counter fear and provide medical advice is a huge challenge as the camps do not have reliable or widespread internet coverage.  
Today, a coalition of 26 aid and humanitarian organisations in Bangladesh – including Plan International – have issued an open letter urging the Bangladeshi and Myanmar Governments to provide reliable internet coverage for the camp, as lack of information fuels fear and panic.

  • ReliefWeb Updates Link: http://reliefweb.int/updates
  • Risk = Hazard + Outrage: The Peter M. Sandman Risk Communication Website Link: http://www.psandman.com/index.htm
  • Stop the Hunger Link: http://www.stopthehunger.com/ Malnutrition and starvation around the world, in real time.
  • Syria Deeply Link: http://www.syriadeeply.org/ Updates on a continuing public-health disaster.
  • The Conversation: Health & Medicine Link: https://theconversation.com/us/health Timely articles by academics in their fields of expertise.
  • Tuberculosis (NewsNow) Link: http://www.newsnow.co.uk/h/?search=tuberculosis&searchheadlines=1
  • Virology News Link: http://www.scoop.it/t/virology-news/ Curated by South African virologist Ed Rybicki.
  • Worldometers Link: http://www.worldometers.info/ Global health statistics in real time.

Bloggers

  • A Time's Memory Link: https://hygimia69.blogspot.com/ Offers highly detailed surveys of news stories and scientific reports.
  • Avian Flu Diary Link: https://afludiary.blogspot.com/ Excellent news coverage and even better analysis.
  • Blog de Medicina Cubana (español) Link: https://medicinacubana.blogspot.ca/

  • Dispatches from Haiti Link: http://blogs.pjstar.com/haiti/ Dr. John Carroll's extraordinary posts and photos.
  • Dying in Haiti Link: https://dyinginhaiti.blogspot.com/ A doctor working in Cité Soleil.
  • E. coli Blog Link: http://www.ecoliblog.com/ Surveillance & analysis on E. coli news & outbreaks
  • Emerging Threats and Infectious Diseases (ETID) Link: https://etidioh.wordpress.com/?iframe=true&theme_preview=true
  • epidemic Link: http://epidemic.bio.ed.ac.uk/ Excellent technical blog on viral diseases.
  • Global Polio Eradication Initiative Link: http://polioeradication.org/
  • Grand Tour Link: https://crofsblogs.typepad.com/tour/ Links to healthcare systems and news about them around the world: Canada, the US, the UK, France, Germany, Sweden, Singapore, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand.
  • HICprevent Link: http://hicprevent.blogs.ahcmedia.com/ Blog of Hospital Infection Control & Prevention
  • Infection Control Tips Link: http://infectioncontrol.tips/ Promising new site on a key issue.
  • Kenny Moise Link: https://moisekenny.wordpress.com/ A Haitian physician and public health researcher.
  • Maia Majumder, Mens et Manus Link: https://maimunamajumder.wordpress.com/
  • Mosquito Research and Management Link: https://cameronwebb.wordpress.com/ Excellent blog by Australian researcher Dr. Cameron Webb.

  • The Incidental Economist Link: https://theincidentaleconomist.com/wordpress/ Blog on health services research.
  • This Day in Water History Link: https://thisdayinwaterhistory.wordpress.com/ Very interesting historical blog.
  • ViroBlogy Link: https://rybicki.wordpress.com/ Dr. Ed Rybicki at the University of Cape Town
  • virology blog Link: http://www.virology.ws/ Dr. Vincent Racaniello offers expert comment and analysis in posts that non-experts can understand.
  • Virology Down Under Link: https://virologydownunder.blogspot.com.au/ Virologist Dr. Ian Mackay's blog

Books on Infectious Diseases

  • Christopher Hamlin: Cholera: The Biography Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/019954624X?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • David M. Oshinsky: Polio: An American Story Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0195307143?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • David Quammen: Ebola: The Natural and Human History of a Deadly Virus Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0393351556?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • David Quammen: Spillover: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0393346617?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Gina Kolata: Flu: The Story Of The Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918 and the Search for the Virus that Caused It Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0743203984?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Jerry Thompson: Cascadia's Fault: The Coming Earthquake and Tsunami that Could Devastate North America Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1582438242?tag=typepad0c2-20 A 9.0 quake will be the biggest public health disaster North America has ever faced.

  • John Kelly: The Great Mortality: An Intimate History of the Black Death, the Most Devastating Plague of All Time Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0060006935?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • John M. Barry: The Great Influenza: The Story of the Deadliest Pandemic in History Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0143036491?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Jonathan M. Katz: The Big Truck That Went By: How the World Came to Save Haiti and Left Behind a Disaster Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1137278978?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Karl Taro Greenfeld: The China Syndrome Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000SEHJLQ?tag=typepad0c2-20 How SARS broke out and was hunted down.

  • Laurie Garrett: Ebola: Story of an Outbreak Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00OYJITEW?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Marilyn Chase: The Barbary Plague: The Black Death in Victorian San Francisco Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0375757082?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Maryn McKenna: Superbug: The Fatal Menace of MRSA Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1416557288?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Maryn McKenna: Beating Back the Devil Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1439123101?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Philip Alcabes: Dread: How Fear and Fantasy have Fueled Epidemics from the Black Death to the Avian Flu Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1586486187?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Ralph R. Frerichs: Deadly River: Cholera and Cover-Up in Post-Earthquake Haiti Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1501702300?tag=typepad0c2-20 The best book I know on the subject.

  • Seth Mnookin: The Panic Virus: The True Story Behind the Vaccine-Autism Controversy Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1439158657?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Sonia Shah: The Fever: How Malaria Has Ruled Humankind for 500,000 Years Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0374230013?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • Sonia Shah: Pandemic: Tracking Contagions, from Cholera to Ebola and Beyond Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0374122881?tag=typepad0c2-20 Highly recommended.

  • Steven Johnson: The Ghost Map: The Story of London's Most Terrifying Epidemic--and How It Changed Science, Cities, and the Modern World Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1594482691?tag=typepad0c2-20

  • William H. McNeill: Plagues and Peoples Link: https://www.amazon.com/dp/0385121229?tag=typepad0c2-20

Ebola

  • #Ebola Link: https://twitter.com/search?f=tweets&vertical=news&q=%23Ebola Very current tweets
  • 7sur7 Link: https://7sur7.cd/category/sante
  • @MSFCongo Link: https://twitter.com/MSFcongo In French.
  • Actualité.cd Link: https://actualite.cd/ In French.
